title: C96-1062

sentences.text: A domain independent model is proposed for the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English .
This model is meant to account for productive rules of interpretation which are inferred from the morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics of the nominal constituents .
In particular , we make extensive use of Pustejovsky 's principles concerning the predicative information associated with nominals .
We argue that it is necessary to draw a line between generalizable semantic principles and domain-specific semantic information .
We explain this distinction and we show how this model may be applied to the interpretation of compounds in real texts , provided that complementary semantic information are retrieved .

Entity-how_this_model_may_be_applied_to_.description: The methodology for applying a domain-independent model to interpret nominal compounds in English by leveraging morpho-semantic characteristics and Pustejovsky's principles.

summary: A domain independent model is proposed for the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English . This model is meant to account for productive rules of interpretation which are inferred from the morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics of the nominal constituents . In particular , we make extensive use of Pustejovsky 's principles concerning the predicative information associated with nominals . We argue that it is necessary to draw a line between generalizable semantic principles and domain-specific semantic information . We explain this distinction and we show how this model may be applied to the interpretation of compounds in real texts , provided that complementary semantic information are retrieved .

Predicate-proposed_for.label: proposed for
Predicate-proposed_for.description: The predicate 'proposed for' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or idea) has been suggested as a solution or approach to achieve or accomplish something described by the object. The connection between the subject and object implies that the subject provides a means, method, or strategy to address or tackle the issue represented by the object.

Predicate-account_for.label: account for
Predicate-account_for.description: To account for a phenomenon or explanation means to identify and explain the underlying causes, factors, or principles that contribute to its occurrence. The predicate 'account for' establishes a relationship between the subject (the entity being explained) and the object (the set of rules, mechanisms, or forces responsible for the phenomenon), indicating that the subject's behavior or characteristics can be understood by considering the object as an explanatory framework.

Predicate-argue_that.label: argue that
Predicate-argue_that.description: To predicate 'argue that' connects the subject with an assertion or proposition, indicating that the subject presents a logical justification or evidence to support the truth of the object. The subject's role is to provide reasoning or proof for the validity of the statement expressed by the object.

Predicate-argue_that_it_is_necessary_to_.label: argue that it is necessary to draw a line between
Predicate-argue_that_it_is_necessary_to_.description: To indicate that there exists a distinction or separation required between two entities (or concepts), categories, or domains, which necessitates drawing a boundary or line to differentiate and understand them separately.

Predicate-explain.label: explain
Predicate-explain.description: To clarify or make understandable the meaning of something by providing a clear and concise account of its significance, purpose, or underlying principles.

Predicate-may_be_applied_to_the_interpre.label: may be applied to the interpretation of compounds in real texts, provided that
Predicate-may_be_applied_to_the_interpre.description: The predicate indicates a condition under which the subject can be used or effective for interpreting compound expressions in natural language texts.

Predicate-may_be_applied.label: may be applied
Predicate-may_be_applied.description: The predicate 'may be applied' indicates a potential or possible connection between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (in this case, an entity such as a model) has the capacity to utilize or implement the information provided by the object (here, how the model may be applied). The phrase implies flexibility and adaptability, allowing for various ways in which the subject can apply the knowledge or principles described.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is subsumed or encompassed by the object concept. In other words, it suggests a hierarchical relationship between the two concepts, where the subject is a more specific instance of the object.
